intro: Galpinsia lampasana, commonly known as the desert bellflower, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant has small, lance-shaped leaves and produces berries that are typically yellow or red when mature. It is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments with minimal water requirements. Galpinsia lampasana is often found in rocky soils and can thrive in full sun.
